items.title: fix string representable and adjust protocol
Removed auto-adding of slash to path in Client
items.body:
All paths were getting an extra slash added at the end, which caused issues with URLs which should not have a slash. I think the path should not be modified after being passed in.

/cc @LoganWright

items.title: Added peerAddress property to Stream
items.body: This aims to fix https://github.com/vapor/vapor/issues/538, as each Stream will now have a chance to vend a address string. I'm open to discussing the name, this just felt correct to me right now.

items.title: Proxy-supplied peerAddress
items.body: Fixes #31. cc @loganwright

items.title: Piping TLS.Config through
Shim for url encoding to allow Turnstile to work
items.body: I'll open up an issue with more details.

items.title: solve empty stream error
items.body:
Solves vapor/vapor#523

I did some detective work and figured out what was causing the empty stream error. It's coming from any client that doesn't send `connection: close`. After one or more request/response pairs have been sent over the wire, the server will loop back over on the respond loop and sit on `readLine()` in the request parser. It will sit on this forever until there is a new HTTP line.

For some reason, it appears that after ~30 seconds (not from Socks timeout) Safari or c sockets or something starts sending 0 length byte arrays. The stream will only ever send empty arrays after this point. So basically if we get an empty stream error that means we need to close it--it's done giving us useful data.

@czechboy0 maybe you might have more insight onto why `recv` is returning a byte array with 0 length instead of a timeout error. When I tried setting a timeout of 30 seconds on `receivingTimeout`, it was successfully timing out, but with a strange error `code 35 ("Resource deadlock avoided")` Is `35` the correct error code for this and just a misleading error message? If so, using the timeouts here might be a more robust solution.

```
Server error: dispatch(Transport.StreamError.receive("There was a problem while receiving data.", Socket failed with code 35 ("Resource deadlock avoided") [readFailed] "Unknown error"))
```

Either way, this seems to fix the issue and the added `defer` statement ensures streams are getting closed even in the case of an error.

items.title: Do not change casing of headers while still matching them case-insensitive
items.body:
Vapor currently changes the casing of HTTP headers, so `MerchantID` becomes `Merchantid`. While this is technically correct (the HTTP standard states that headers are case-insensitive), it causes problems when communicating with some API's that don't adhere to this rule.

This PR changes the implementation of `HeaderKey` to store the key in it's original casing. I changed `hashValue` and the `==` operator to use a lowercased version of the keys for comparison, so subscripting a `[HeaderKey : String]` with `content-type` will still match `Content-Type` and also `HeaderKey("content-type") == HeaderKey("Content-Type")` still evaluates to `true`.

items.title: Middleware
add user agent
items.body: Fixes #54

items.title: Add methods to append and remove path components from URIs
items.body: Adds `appendingPathComponent`, `deletingLastPathComponent`, and `removingPath` to the public API for `URI`.

items.title: Added a final check to ensure the socket is closed
items.body: @tannernelson and I were discussing about servers going down because of `Server error: accept(Socket failed with code 24 ("Too many open files") [acceptFailed] "Unknown error")` caused by `Client` not closing the socket.

items.title: Changed Response Header comparison to lowercase as common ground
items.body:
Some Websockets respond with a lowercase “upgrade” or an uppercase
“WebSocket” string. Therefore a broader check for the headers is
necessary.

items.title: peerAddress is now reported correctly for TLS server sockets
items.body:
For connections created by calling accept() on a server TLS socket, the
peerAddress would always be reported as 0.0.0.0, because the actual
socket is referenced by currSocket.

items.title: properly add read timeout to socks stream
Enable nonblocking operation
items.body:
This PR is part of a series to enable nonblocking operation in Vapor and solve https://github.com/vapor/engine/issues/66

This PR depends on https://github.com/vapor/socks/pull/86.

~~If this PR is accepted, Vapor needs to be updated with https://github.com/vapor/vapor/pull/690 to work again.~~

items.title: Nsclient
items.body: Just starting to put out there, probably some more cleanup to do.

items.title: SMTP date formatter now works in non-US locales
items.body:
- SMTPDateFormatter is now always initialized with an en-US locale (which is what RFC 2822 implicitly expects).
- Fixed a test which used to fail in some timezones, because 1970-01-01 00:00 UTC is 1969-12-31 in the US

items.title: Changed Stream tests to use httpbin.org instead of google.com
items.body:
Stream tests were failing for non-US developers because the page at
google.com looks different, depending on the user’s location and
language. The expected string “Search the world's information” seems to
appear only on the US version of google.com.
